newsitem.title: FINLAND: UPM says made bid for Repap.
newsitem.headline: UPM says made bid for Repap.

text.p: Finnish forest industry group UPM-Kymmene Oy late last year submitted a bid to acquire some parts of Canadian LWC paper maker Repap Enterprises Inc, UPM executive vice president Martin Granholm said on Tuesday.

"It is true that we showed interest (to buy) certain parts (of Repap) at that time but the issue became void when Repap received an offer for its entire shareholding," Granholm told a Reuters reporter.
He was asked to comment on a report in business daily Kauppalehti, which said UPM had bid in late 1996 for Repap and was likely to do so again if the opportunity presented itself.

"The situation is still exactly at that stage," Granholm said referring to Canadian pulp and paper group Avenor Inc's bid for Repap, the success or failure of which is due to become clear on Wednesday.
"What may possibly be on its way we will return to at a later stage," Granholm said. He did not elaborate.

Avenor has made a C2.6 billion ($1.9 billion) offer to acquire Repap, but the plan was put in doubt on Monday after Canada's largest pension fund, which holds a 10 percent stake in Avenor, gave the deal a thumbs down and other institutional holders indicated they would also vote against the merger.
The merger of Avenor and Repap, both Montreal-based pulp and paper companies, was due to close if shareholders approved it on Wednesday. But it has met with significant shareholder resistance.
Avenor earlier this month cut its stock and debt offer to one Avenor share for every eight Repap shares and excluded Repap's British Columbia operations from the deal.
The original bid was one Avenor share for every 4.25 Repap shares, plus the assumption of C2.4 billion ($1.7 billion) in debt.

Kauppalehti said Repap's past strategy to buy undervalued paper and pulp mills and modernise them with debt financing had given it modern machinery and a leading position in light-weight-coated paper in North America.
Repap's downsides were its debts and pulp production, it said. --Helsinki newsroom +358-9-680 50 245, e-mail news@reuters.fi
